title: Filed chapter 7 w/o atty. trustee says I lied about income and now wants me in chapter 13. I didn't lie I was mistaken. Dismiss?
question: I want to know if I can just let this dismiss and revisit it in the future with an attorney or what I should I do. Basically, I didn't include my overtime in the means test calculation because I didn't know I had to.
answers:
In the U.S. Bankruptcy Court for the Central District of California, a debtor can file a motion to voluntarily dismiss the bankruptcy case, but the bankruptcy court may or may not approve the dismissal depending upon the chapter number of the bankruptcy case and the prior history of the debtor in bankruptcy.

It is extremely important to note that dismissal of a bankruptcy case has serious consequences. For example, if a bankruptcy case is voluntarily dismissed, it may affect a debtor’s rights to the automatic stay in a future bankruptcy case.

Moreover, because a Chapter 7 bankruptcy trustee is appointed, the trustee may file an objection to a request for voluntary dismissal, and a hearing is required. (See Bankruptcy Code Section 707.)

You should consult with a bankruptcy attorney now, rather than later.

The only reason the Ch.7 Trustee would be upset is if your income is above the limit for Ch.7 after adding in your overtime pay. If the Ch.7 Trustee is correct (sometimes they err, so you should double check the math) then you are NOT QUALIFIED to file Ch.7 due to your income, AT THIS TIME.

If you do NOT want to be in Ch.13, then you only have two options NOW: let the Ch.7 Trustee dismiss it OR make the effort to dismiss it yourself. You likely filed Ch.7 because you NEEDED TO, so don't shoot yourself in the foot by letting the Ch.7 Trustee do the work now, but end up with problems down the road. IT LOOKS BAD and can have long term damage if you force the Ch.7 Trustee to make the effort to dismiss your case. The problems could include: 180 day bar to refiling, a court record that looks like you got caught trying to pull a fast one on the system, and potential non-dischargeability of your debts if there are findings of bad faith or abuse of process.

I urge you to do the work (even if you need to hire counsel) to explain to the Court your ERROR (which is understandable if you admit it and say you're sorry to the court) and politely and respectfully request your case be dismissed WITHOUT a bar. The Central District of California (Riverside) has a STANDARD FORM to request dismissal of a Chapter 13 case. You can't use that form to request dismissal of your Ch.7 case, but you can look at the form and copy most of it to use as a request to dismiss your case. See also section 707 of the Bankruptcy Code.

REMEMBER, the income test is only for the LAST 6 months. Many types of jobs have seasonal or fluctuating overtime. For example, if you are a salmon fisherman, you will work lots of overtime in the Spring/Summer and earn TONS of money. However, your income over the winter may drop way below the Ch.7 test. If your situation is like this, you may just need to wait a few months (without working overtime) until your 6 month average is below the cutoff point for your family size. If this might happen to you, you DEFINITELY want to make sure you can file your Chapter 7 case again later without all the bad JooJoo that comes with letting the Ch.7 Trustee dismiss your case for cause!

Good luck.

Yes, you can let it dismiss. However, if you have not filled out section IV and V of the Means Test you should do that to see if you qualify for a chapter 7 that way. Simply amend your income to include your overtime and use the Federal Deductions, Deductions for living expenses and the Deductions for debt payment to determine your monthly disposable income. If your monthly disposable income is less than $117 you can keep your existing Chapter 7. You might qualify that way and save the time and money you already have into your present Bankruptcy case.

If your bankruptcy case is dismissed by a chapter 7 trustee, there can be some unexpected consequences that you are not considering. You may be ineligible to ever discharge the debts you listed in your defective Chapter 7 case if it is dismissed by the Trustee.

Get to an experienced bankruptcy attorney right away. It might be possible to save this case, or there may be other strategies that can help you.

Bottom line, it doesn't matter whether you lied or simply made a mistake! If you don't qualify to file Chapter 7, you can't obtain the benefits of a Chapter 7.

Hope this perspective helps!
